newsitem.title: HUNGARY: FOCUS - HUNGARY SEES NEW RATING UPGRADING WAVE.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - HUNGARY SEES NEW RATING UPGRADING WAVE.

text.p: European credit rating agency IBCA's decision to place its rating to Hungary with positive outlook should be the first step of a wave of upgradings, National Bank of Hungary (NBH) president Gyorgy Suranyi said on Friday.
IBCA, which currently rates Hungary at BBB-, announced earlier on Friday that it had placed Hungary's long-term foreign currency rating with positive implications.
"I hope that the other rating agencies will evaluate similarly what has happened in the recent period," Suranyi told Reuters.
One year ago, IBCA was the first international rating agency to grant Hungary an investment grade. Later in 1996 all major rating agencies followed the step.

IBCA said on Friday that Hungary's economic fundamentals were strong, the structural adjustment advanced well, aconomic recovery was underway and the external current account position was sustainable.

Suranyi said he was glad to hear IBCA's announcement, but he added that rating agencies usually followed the improvement of Hungary's judgement on international debt markets only with a very long delay.
"I also hope that the time differential between the market's evaluation and the rating agencies' devaluation will somewhat shorten," he said.
"The judgement gf the market has been substantially more favourable for the past one and the half year than rating agencies'," he added.
However, the upgradings would not be so important for Hungary this year than they were in 1996, Suranyi said.
"The real difference is between investment and non-investment grade, and this breakthrough came last year."
Suranyi denied market talks that the NBH decided to launch soon 10 year dollar bonds of $300 million to $1 billion.
However, he confirmed that the NBH was considering tapping the international market with a benchmark bond.
"If every condition is clearly favourable, we don't exclude that we will enter the market."
Suranyi confirmed reports of business daily Vilaggazdasag that the NBH had to extend its licence for issuing papers in the U.S. recently.
Along with the extension, the NBH also raised the limit amount to $1 billion by $250 million, sparking speculation on the market, the paper added.
